oai_dc:dc.dc:title: V-mail letter from Sergeant John B. Johnson to Ann Cashel, Nashville, Tennessee, 1944 August 08
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A V-mail letter from Sergeant John B. Johnson to Ann Cashel, 1025 Iverson Avenue, dated August 8th, 1944. In the letter he states that “today marks 34 months in the army” and that “recently …. I was privileged to visit the ruins of Pompeii … [that] in addition to the ruins, in the present city of Pompeii there is a cathedral which is second to the Vatican in beauty.” He also states: “Naples is quite a nice city although both our own armies and those of the enemy did a pretty thorough job in tearing up the place.” He states in closing that “Most of us would be willing to dispense with all afternoons off if it would get this war over with any sooner, but like machinery we need an occasional idling period, too.” Miss Cashel graduated from Saint Cecilia Academy in Nashville, Tennessee, June, 1922. The 1930 Census cites her birth date abt. 1905, residing at home with her widowed mother Katie B. Cashel, at a 10th Ave. N address in Ward 2 of the City of Nashville, Tennessee. The names of her parents are: William Patrick Cashel and Katie (nee Moran) Cashel. Forms part of the John Lawrence Connelly Collection, 1 letter.
